Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs and Co-PIs of grants supported through the NSF-NIH-ANR-BMBF-BSF Collaborative Research in Computational Neuroscience (CRCNS) program meet annually. This eleventh meeting of CRCNS investigators brings together a broad spectrum of computational neuroscience researchers supported by the program, and includes poster presentations, talks, plenary lectures, and workshops.
The meeting is scheduled for September 28-30, 2015 and is hosted by the University of Washington.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved organizing and hosting the annual meeting of scientists, also known as Principle Investigators (PIs), who are funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) and its collaborators through the grant program known as "Collaborative Research in Computational Neuroscience," or CRCNS for short.  The goal of this CRCNS PI meeting is to foster interactions between scientists who study the function of neurons and nervous systems using experimental and computational techniques. Computational and quantitative approaches for studying the brain and nervous system have been a part of neuroscience since its beginnings as a field. However, recent advances in the ability to collect large data sets, in the ability to create and run very large simulations and in the development of new data analysis approaches are leading to an even more central role for computational approaches in this field.  We held the annual meeting in Seattle, WA on the campus of the University of Washington (UW) from September 28th to 30th, 2015, and we invited all CRCNS grant PIs to present their work at the meeting, either in the form of an oral or a poster presentation.  We invited additional distinguished plenary speakers to present new advances and potential new research directions in computational neuroscience.  We also organized a special 1-day workshop about the intersection of neuroscience and machine learning to provide additional opportunities for discussion and collaboration with both scientists and researchers from industry.  We ended up hosting over one hundred registered attendees, and many graduate students attended from training programs at UW.  The meeting generated much discussion and interaction among scientists, engineers and funding representatives from the NSF, the National Institutes of Health (NIH) and from affiliated funding organizations of foreign collaborating countries.  This meeting is a key annual event for facilitating fundamental scientific research that seeks to deepen our understanding of the brain.


Last Modified: 02/13/2017
Modified by: Wyeth Bair

The meeting generated much discussion and interaction among scientists, engineers and funding representatives from the NSF, the National Institutes of Health (NIH) and from affiliated funding organizations of foreign collaborating countries.
